definition:
Let $f(n)$ and $F(n)$ be functions from
$\mathbb{Z}^{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$. We say that $f(n)$ has [*normal
order*]{} $F(n)$ if for each $\epsilon>0$ the set
$$A(\epsilon)=\{n \in \mathbb{Z}^{+} :
     (1-\epsilon)F(n)<f(n)<(1+\epsilon)F(n) \}$$ has the property that
$\underline{d}(A(\epsilon))=1$. Equivalently, if
$B(\epsilon)=\mathbb{Z}^{+} \backslash A(\epsilon)$, then
$\underline{d}(B(\epsilon))=0$. (Note that $\underline{d}(X)$ denotes
the lower asymptotic density of $X$).

We say that $f$ has [*average order*]{} $F$ if
$$\sum_{j=1}^n f(j) \sim \sum_{j=1}^n F(j)$$
